text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Philips Electronics books 590 million guilders loss in 1996; all sectors of company affected. (p1)
- Royal Dutch/Shell surprises with strong fourth quarter. (p1)
- The Netherlands attracted more foreign investments than Germany in 1995, according to European statisics office Eurostat. (p1)
- Natural gas company Gasunie to sell 30 bn cubic metres of gas to Poland in next 15 years. (p3)
- Bank insurer ING expands in Canadian market with takeover of Canadian Surety Company. (p3)
- Small investors in Pirelli Tyre Holding have little faith in parent company's bid. (p3)
- Mould maker Axxicon forecasts a slight rise in net earnings and operating profits this year. (p4)
- Technical wholesaler Otra reports 69 pct drop in 1996 net; company gives no forecast. (p5)
VOLKSKRANT
- The Netherlands supports plan for extra high VAT on energy in Europe. (p1)
- Supermarket chain Edah to launch customer cards without chip for electronic payments. (p2)
- Mobile phone company Libertel expects problems if payments for licence are too high. (p2)
- Financial reserves of Amsterdam port's labour pool SHB nearly depleted. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Cabinet aims to triple use of environment-friendly energy sources like sun and wind in year 2000. (p1)
- Port of Rotterdam introduces fraud-free identification system for containers in April. (p3)
- Unions and management of Hoogovens reach pay and conditions agreement with no forced redundancies. (p3)
- Entrepreneur Willem Smit seeks Nasdaq listing for his automation firm Internoc. (p29)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Dutch industrial production grows two percent in 1996. (p11)
TROUW
- Traffic minister Annemarie Jorritsma fears that curbing Amsterdam Schiphol Airport's growth might be against European rulings. (p1)
- Plans for aircraft maker Fokker's restart have a "reasonable chance of success", say well-informed sources. (p7)
